poem:
"Upon Santiago de Compostela"

500 miles or prison,
a young man steps towards transformation.
Beneath Spanish skies, every rock,
a testament to human weight.
Sister pilgrim, eyes as open questions,
finds a mystery marinated in humanity. 
Paths unfold in sync with his probation
continuously unfolding, 
like the petals of a slow blooming flower
Under the counsel of tired shoes.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A modern pilgrimage’s transformative power | Letters Re your editorial (The Guardian view on pilgrimage: a 21st-century spiritual exercise, 14 April), my sister has just completed her third pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela in Spain. On this trip she met a young man who was walking the 500 miles with his probation officer. He had had the choice of walking the Camino or going to prison; for what offence she did not discover, but over". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
